result.content:
Problem A. DZY Loves Chessboard

Imagine all the cells of the board were good, what will be the perfect pattern?

It will be the chessboard pattern.


-------------------------------------
| B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B |
-------------------------------------
| W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W |
-------------------------------------
| B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B |
-------------------------------------
| W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W |
-------------------------------------
| B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B |
-------------------------------------
| W | B | W | B | W | B | W | B | W |
-------------------------------------

Now imagine after we colour all the cells with this pattern ... If we turn any of the cells into bad cells, this would not affect the validity of the pattern.

So all we have to do is to colour all the board with this pattern, and then cover all bad cells.

Problem B. Mashmokh and Lights

This is a direct implementation problem.

We will process the buttons clicked one by one.

For every button, we check for all the light with index greater than or equal to the index of the button, and turn them off if they are still turned on, and remember that the current button closed it.

Problem C. Two Substrings

This was somehow a tricky problem.

For the first thought, one can generate all occurrences of the string "AB" and then generate all occurrences of the string "BA", and then compare every pair of occurrences and check if they overlap.

But there is an easier way to solve it.

We can just find the first occurrence of the string "AB" and the last occurrence of the string "BA" and check if they overlap.

And we also find the first occurrence of the string "BA" and the last occurrence of the string "AB" and check if they overlap.

We are guaranteed to find an answer this way if it exists.

Problem D. Valuable Resources

Let's first assume that we are required to build a rectangular city.

The solution for the task would be getting the maximum and minimum X coordinate among all points and the difference between maxX and minX will determine one of the side lengths of the rectangle.

The difference between maxY and minY will determine the other side length.

Now to convert this rectangle into a square without losing any resources, we will expand the smaller side length to be equal to the bigger side length.

Problem E. Two Buttons

This problem can be visualized as a standard graph problem, where every number representing a node and the buttons represent edges between the nodes.

So we need to calculate shortest path in an un-weighted directed graph. The easiest way to do this is using breadth first search algorithm (bfs).

The most tricky part is determining the upper limit for the numbers in the graph.

We can't set the upper limit to 10^4 because the blue button allows us to decrease the number, which means we can exceed the required number and then use the blue button to reach our required number.

But obviously we will not need to increase the number more than 2*10^4, since the starting number is always less than 10^4.

So the upper limit should be any number >= 2 * 10^4

Problem F. Divisibility by Eight

This problem has lots of solution, I will try to describe the easiest one.

First of all if the given number includes at least one zero, we can take this zero as our output, just like the second sample input.

Now we should make some observation about divisibility by 8.

A number is divisible by 8 if and only if its last three digits form a number that is divisible by eight.

This means that if we have a number consisting of three digits and we added a fourth digit to its left, this wont change it divisibility by 8.

So we will just try every possible number of 1, 2, or 3 digits that we can form out of the given number and check if it is divisible by 8.
